directivesynopsis.name: Group
directivesynopsis.description: Group under which the server will answer requests

usage.p: The Group directive sets the group under which the server will answer requests. In order to use this directive, the server must be run initially as root. If you start the server as a non-root user, it will fail to change to the specified group, and will instead continue to run as the group of the original user. Unix-group is one of:

dl.dd: Refers to the given group by name.
Refers to a group by its number.

usage.p: It is recommended that you set up a new group specifically for running the server. If the configured User is a member of any supplementary groups, the process will also become a member of these groups.

note.title: Security
note.p: Don't set Group (or User) to root unless you know exactly what you are doing, and what the dangers are. It is not recommended to use the group nobody, which is not intended for use by long-running daemons.

directivesynopsis.name: User
directivesynopsis.description: The userid under which the server will answer requests

usage.p: The User directive sets the user ID as which the server will answer requests. In order to use this directive, the server must be run initially as root. If you start the server as a non-root user, it will fail to change to the lesser privileged user, and will instead continue to run as that original user. If you do start the server as root, then it is normal for the parent process to remain running as root. Unix-userid is one of:

dl.dd: Refers to the given user by name.
Refers to a user by its number.

usage.p: The user should have no privileges that result in it being able to access files that are not intended to be visible to the outside world, and similarly, the user should not be able to execute code that is not meant for HTTP requests. It is recommended that you set up a new user and group specifically for running the server.

note.title: Security
note.p: Don't set User (or Group) to root unless you know exactly what you are doing, and what the dangers are. It is not recommended to use the user nobody, which is not intended for use by long-running daemons.

directivesynopsis.name: ChrootDir
directivesynopsis.description: Directory for apache to run chroot(8) after startup.

usage.p: This directive tells the server to chroot(8) to the specified directory after startup, but before accepting requests over the 'net.

Note that running the server under chroot is not simple, and requires additional setup, particularly if you are running scripts such as CGI or PHP. Please make sure you are properly familiar with the operation of chroot before attempting to use this feature.

directivesynopsis.name: Suexec
directivesynopsis.description: Enable or disable the suEXEC feature
directivesynopsis.default: On if suexec binary exists with proper owner and mode, Off otherwise

usage.p: When On, startup will fail if the suexec binary doesn't exist or has an invalid owner or file mode.
When Off, suEXEC will be disabled even if the suexec binary exists and has a valid owner and file mode.
